newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Wife publishes love letter to spouse denying split.
newsitem.headline: Wife publishes love letter to spouse denying split.

text.p: The wife of one of Australias most senior policemen on Tuesday published an extraordinary letter to her husband on the front page of a Sydney tabloid newspaper, declaring her love and denying rumours of a split.
"Sweetheart, I love you. Dont let the bastards get you down," wrote Adrienne Ryan, whose husband Peter Ryan is police commissioner in Australias most populous state, New South Wales.

Adrienne Ryan, who returned to Britain two weeks ago to finish a university course, wrote the letter to the Sydney-based The Daily Telegraph newspaper after recent reports in Australian media of a marriage break-up.
Peter Ryan, a Briton, was appointed in 1996 to head the New South Wales force, wracked by revelations of widespread corruption.

Adrienne Ryan, a former London police officer more than 15 years younger than her husband, said she would follow him "to the ends of the earth" and accused disgruntled police of spreading rumours of a marriage split to undermine his leadership.

"If they think for a moment that petty innuendo can affect him professionally then they have failed to get the true measure of the man," she wrote. "I suggest they think again and think fast. This man is here to stay and he will see the job through with his family by his side."
The Ryans have two young daughters.
"I adore my husband for he is all that anyone could ask of a husband and father: devoted, loving and caring without reservation, and we have a strong and enduring marriage," she wrote.
The New South Wales police force is Australias oldest and largest, but it has also been regarded as the most corrupt.
Peter Ryan was national director of the Police Training College in England when he was appointed to his new Australian job last June.
